title: Fundamentals of Budgeting and Variance Analysis
headline: Learn about the importance of budgeting, types of budgeting as well as variance analysis from this free online course.
description: This free online course on the fundamentals of budgeting and variance analysis provides a comprehensive guide on the impact of budgeting in cost accounting. Learn about the importance of having a budgetary control system as well as the concept of standard cost, the steps involved in standard cost as well as the formulas for calculating material cost and labour variance. Start this course and improve your knowledge of budgeting and variance.
courseDescription:
This free online course will begin by introducing you to the concept of budgeting and budgetary control in cost accounting. You will learn about the importance of having a budgetary control system in an organisation, the objectives of budgeting, the various types of budgeting available in cost accounting, the different components of a functional budget as well as how resources are co-ordinated and allocated to two different functions in cost accounting.

This course will also introduce you to how to compute budget contribution margin using illustrations. This course will teach you about the importance of cash budgeting in cost accounting, the concept of standard costing, along with its steps. You will learn about types of standard, the advantages along with the disadvantages of standard costing in cost accounting, as well as the meaning of material cost variance.

Finally, this course will introduce you to the formula for computing material cost variance as well as the formula for calculating labour variance. This course will give you insights to the reasons why an organization faces overhead variance along with the reasons for labour cost variance in cost accounting. Start this course and improve your understanding of budgeting and variance analysis in cost accounting.

  • Lesson Summary
    • Budgeting is usually an estimated statement prepared by companies as well as the government to attain some goals. A budget typically includes income, expenditure, and employment capital.
    • A budget is a financial or quantitative statement prepared and approved before a defined period of time of policy to be pursued during that purpose for attending a given objective.
    • Budgetary control means the establishment of budgets relating to the responsibilities of executives to the prerequisites of policy and the continuous evaluation of actual with budgeted results either to secure by individual action the objective of that action or to provide a base for its base. 
    • The objectives of budgeting as enumerated in this module are planning, directing, and controlling.  
    • Budgetary control is a process in which actuals are compared with the budget to analyse variances and corrective actions are initiated. 
    • The types of budget identified in this module are fixed budget versus flexible budget, functional versus master's budget,  long term versus short term/current budget, and zero-based budget.
    • Functional budget is the type of budget that relates to individual functions or tasks in an organization. Functional budget can be grouped into physical, cost, and profit budgets.
    • The cash budget is a component of the functional budget and serves as a basis for the scientific estimation of the cash requirement of a company.

  • Lesson Summary
    • Standard cost is a pre-determined cost which is calculated from the management's standard of efficient operation and the relevant necessary expenditure. In other words, standard cost is a a proposed cost which will be incurred provided the operations are made very efficiently.
    • The steps in standard cost are; setting the standard cost itself, study the actual cost, and carrying out the cost variance analysis.
    • The types of standard covered in this module are ideal standard, normal standard, basic or bogey standard, and current standard.
    • Variance means the difference between standard costing and the actual cost of output. A variance may be favourable or unfavourable Variance was also divided into controllable and uncontrollable in this module.
    • Variance analysis is the analysis of the cost variance into its component parts with justification for such variance so that a corrective approach can be adopted.
    • Variance could occur due to effective or ineffective use of materials, labour, change in material prices, standard labour rates, standard allowances for indirect labour, and so on.
    • The formula for calculating material cost variance is (standard quantity multiplied by standard price) minus (actual quantity multiplied by actual price).
    • The formula for calculating labour variance is (standard hours multiplied by standard rate per hour) minus (actual hours multiplied by actual rate per hour).
